com.pixolus.meterreading

Class MeterReadingView

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.view.View
      • android.view.ViewGroup
        • android.widget.FrameLayout
          • com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Drawable.Callback, AccessibilityEventSource, KeyEvent.Callback, ViewManager, ViewParent

    public final class MeterReadingView
extends FrameLayout
    A view to perform optical meter and barcode reading.

    Integrate a meter reading view in your layout by placing it in the layout XML file. You should specify CameraViewListener, MeterReadingViewListener, and/or BarcodeReadingViewListener using setCameraViewListener(com.pixolus.meterreading.CameraViewListener), setMeterReadingViewListener(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingViewListener), and/or setBarcodeReadingViewListener(com.pixolus.meterreading.BarcodeReadingViewListener) to be able to receive events and results from the view.

    You can place the view anywhere in your Layout. It will present a live camera view and process the video data to find and read meters and/or barcodes. After camera initialization, it will call CameraViewListener.onCameraViewCameraReady(MeterReadingView) in your listener.

    When your listener implements the MeterReadingViewListener interface, as soon as results are found, they will be reported by calling onScanReadings() passing a list of MeterReadingResult instances, a Bitmap and metadata.

    In case your listener implements the BarcodeReadingViewListener interface, scanned barcodes will be reported by calling onScanBarcodes() passing a list of BarcodeReadingResult instances, a Bitmap and metadata.

    The MeterReadingView will carry on processing video after results were found, so the onScanReadings and onScanBarcodes callback may be invoked multiple times unless you destroy the fragment, set setNumberOfCounters(int) to 0 or set setBarcodeFormats(ArrayList) to an empty list.

    When the view is re-instantiated during state restore (e.g. due to an orientation change of the device) and the camera device's torch/flashlight was on, it will be shortly switched off and then on again. This is expected behavior.

    Note that because the camera hardware is an exclusive resource, you need to make sure that only a single instance of the MeterReadingView exists at any time within your app, otherwise an alert dialog will be displayed, warning that the camera could not be accessed. Views in an activity are automatically re-instantiated during state restore (e.g. orientation change of the device). So if you manually instantiate a MeterReadingView (e.g. in your activity's Activity.onCreate(Bundle) method) you have to pay extra attention. In case your activity is not restarted on device rotation, i.e. you handle configuration changes in your activity's Activity.onConfigurationChanged(android.content.res.Configuration) method, do not forget to also call View.onConfigurationChanged(android.content.res.Configuration).

    Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter and barcode reading for your application scenario.

    • Field Detail

      • AUTOMATIC

        public static final int AUTOMATIC
        Constant indicating unknown or arbitrary number of digits and counters.

        This constant can be used for integerDigits, fractionDigits, and numberOfCounters. In general, choosing automatic mode makes detection more flexible but bears a risk that a result is returned although not all information is visible (yet). For example, part of a counter may be hidden behind a reflection on the cover glass while the other part is well legible. The detection can only return the visible part.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        See Also:
        setIntegerDigits(int), setFractionDigits(int), setNumberOfCounters(int), Constant Field Values

      • INVALID

        public static final int INVALID
        Constant invalidating a configuration.

        This is the default value for integerDigits, fractionDigits, and numberOfCounters. If one of these properties is set to INVALID, a warning message is shown in the camera preview about the invalid configuration and no meters will be read.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        See Also:
        setIntegerDigits(int), setFractionDigits(int), setNumberOfCounters(int), Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • dispatchDraw

        protected void dispatchDraw(Canvas canvas)
        Overrides:
        dispatchDraw in class ViewGroup

      • isArchitectureSupported

        public static boolean isArchitectureSupported()
        Check whether the current hardware platform is supported by the pixometer SDK. When this method is not called and the current architecture is not supported, an overlay is presented to the user stating that meter reading is not possible as the platform is not supported and that `isArchitectureSupported()` method should be checked. When the current architecture is not supported, no meter reading can be performed. Therefore, the user should be presented some advice to manually capture a picture of the meter and enter the meter reading manually.
        Returns:
        True on supported hardware platforms, false otherwise.

      • enableView

        public void enableView()
        Enable the MeterReadingView. By calling this method you can resume the meter and barcode reading, as well as the camera preview. You can use this after the camera was temporarily freed using disableView(). You should call this method in your onResume method.

      • disableView

        public void disableView()
        Disable the MeterReadingView. By calling this method you can pause the meter and barcode reading, as well as the camera preview. You can e.g. use this to temporarily free the camera, without completely destroying the view. Afterwards you can re-enable the view using enableView(). You should call this method in your onPause method.

      • setIntegerDigits

        public void setIntegerDigits(int integerDigits)
        The number of integer digits present on the meter to be read by the receiver.

        Allowed values are 1, ..., 12 and AUTOMATIC.

        The default value is INVALID.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        Parameters:
        integerDigits - Either the number of integer digits on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

      • getIntegerDigits

        public int getIntegerDigits()
        Return the number of integer digits present on the meter to be read by the receiver.
        Returns:
        Either the number of integer digits on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

      • setFractionDigits

        public void setFractionDigits(int fractionDigits)
        The number of fraction digits present on the meter to be read by the receiver.

        Allowed values are 0, ..., 8 and AUTOMATIC.

        The default value is INVALID.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        Parameters:
        fractionDigits - Either the number of fraction digits on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

        Returns:
        Either the number of fraction digits on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

      • setNumberOfCounters

        public void setNumberOfCounters(int numberOfCounters)
        The number of counters present on the meter to be read by the receiver.

        Allowed values are 0, ..., 2 and AUTOMATIC.

        You may set this value to 0, in which case the MeterReadingViewListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) callback is never called.

        The default value is INVALID.

        Please refer to the "Configuring_the_SDK.md" file in the root folder of the pixometer SDK for an in-depth discussion of how to properly configure the meter reading for your application scenario.

        Parameters:
        numberOfCounters - Either the number of counters on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

      • getNumberOfCounters

        public int getNumberOfCounters()
        Return the number of counters present on the meter to be read by the receiver.
        Returns:
        Either the number of counters on the meter, or one of the constants AUTOMATIC or INVALID.

      • setRegionOfInterestInsets

        public boolean setRegionOfInterestInsets(Rect regionOfInterestInsets)
        Set region of interest insets to restrict meter reading to a specific area defined in absolute values.

        You can use this property to disallow processing at screen edges. As a general rule, you should set this property such that the space covered by user interface elements is not used for processing. For example, in order to spare out translucent areas covered by navigation bars etc..

        To create a dead area of 50 pixels on the left, 60 on the top, 50 on the right and 200 on the bottom, you can use this method as follows: setRegionOfInterestInsets(new Rect(50, 60, 50, 200));

        Parameters:
        regionOfInterestInsets - The insets in view coordinates to define a "dead area" where no processing shall be performed.
        Returns:
        False, when regionOfInterestInsets is larger than the view or insets are negative.
        See Also:
        setRegionOfInterestRelativeInsets(android.graphics.RectF)

      • getRegionOfInterestInsets

        @Nonnull
public final Rect getRegionOfInterestInsets()
        Get the region of interest insets which restrict the meter reading to a specific area.
        Returns:
        The region of interest insets in view coordinates, defining a "dead area" where no processing shall be performed.

      • getRegionOfInterest

        @Nullable
public final Rect getRegionOfInterest()
        Get the region of interest which restricts the meter reading to a specific area.
        Returns:
        The region of interest in view coordinates, defining the area of the view in which processing shall be performed. May return `null` before the first layout of the views of the receiver.

      • setShowRegionOfInterest

        public void setShowRegionOfInterest(boolean showRegionOfInterest)
        Turn on or off the drawing of the region of interest.

        This includes drawing a border around the region of interest and filling the area outside of the region of interest.

      • setRegionOfInterestRelativeInsets

        public boolean setRegionOfInterestRelativeInsets(RectF regionOfInterestInsets)
        Set region of interest insets to restrict meter reading to a specific area defined in relative values.

        You can use this property to disallow processing at screen edges. As a general rule, you should set this property such that the space covered by user interface elements is not used for processing. For example, in order to spare out translucent areas covered by navigation bars etc..

        To create a dead area of 10% on the left, 20% on the top, 15% on the right and 50% on the bottom, you can use this method as follows: setRegionOfInterestRelativeInsets(new RectF(0.1f, 0.2f, 0.15f, 0.5f));

        Parameters:
        regionOfInterestInsets - The insets in the range of 0-1 to define a "dead area" where no processing shall be performed.
        Returns:
        False, when regionOfInterestInsets is larger than the view or insets are negative.
        See Also:
        setRegionOfInterestInsets(android.graphics.Rect)

      • setBarcodeCaptureAnimation

        public void setBarcodeCaptureAnimation(MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation barcodeCaptureAnimation)
        Set the MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation to be shown after successful barcode reading.

        If you plan to verify detected barcode results in your implementation of the BarcodeReadingViewListener.onScanBarcodes(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.BarcodeReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) method, you might want to decide when to show the capture animation. You can therefore disable the automatic start of the animation by passing MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation.NONE to this method and call animateCapture(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation) to show the animation or implement your own.

        Default animation: MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation.NONE

        Parameters:
        barcodeCaptureAnimation - The MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation to be performed whenever a new barcode was detected, i.e. when BarcodeReadingViewListener.onScanBarcodes(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.BarcodeReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) is called.

      • getBarcodeCaptureAnimation

        public MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation getBarcodeCaptureAnimation()
        Return the current MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation to be shown after successful barcode detection.
        Returns:
        The MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation that will automatically be shown after successful barcode detection.

      • setMeterReadingCaptureAnimation

        public void setMeterReadingCaptureAnimation(MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation meterReadingCaptureAnimation)
        Set the MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation to be shown after successful meter reading.

        If you plan to verify meter reading results in your implementation of the MeterReadingViewListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) method, you might want to decide when to show the capture animation. You can therefore disable the automatic start of the animation by passing MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation.NONE to this method and call animateCapture(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation) to show the animation or implement your own.

        Default animation: MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation.FLASH

        Parameters:
        meterReadingCaptureAnimation - The MeterReadingView.CaptureAnimation to be performed when a new meter reading was scanned, i.e. when MeterReadingViewListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) is called.

      • isTorchOn

        public boolean isTorchOn()
        Return the current state of the device's torch/flashlight.

        This method shall not be called before CameraViewListener.onCameraViewCameraReady(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView) was called. (You may safely call it from your implementation of the onCameraViewCameraReady() callback.)

        Returns:
        true if the torch is currently on; false otherwise. If the device does not have a torch, false is returned.

      • setTorchOn

        public boolean setTorchOn(boolean torchOn)
        Switch the device's torch/flashlight on or off. Invoking this method has no effect if the device does not have a torch.

        This method shall not be called before CameraViewListener.onCameraViewCameraReady(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView)} was called. (You may safely call it from your implementation of the onCameraViewCameraReady() callback.)

        Parameters:
        torchOn - if true, the torch will be turned on; otherwise the torch will be turned off
        Returns:
        True on success.

      • initiateManualCapture

        public void initiateManualCapture()
        Initiate a capture of the next available image, even if no meter can be read.

        Invoke this method when you want to capture the image even if no counters could be found or read. Shortly after this method returns, your MeterReadingViewListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) callback will be invoked. (Note that it is possible that a counter could be successfully read after you invoke this method, so you should still inspect the results provided to your callback even if you previously initiated a manual capture using this method.)

      • isResultsOverlayVisible

        public boolean isResultsOverlayVisible()
        Return the visibility of an overlay that shows reading results.
        Returns:
        true if MeterReadingFragment displays results overlay; false otherwise. Defaults to true.

      • setResultsOverlayVisible

        public void setResultsOverlayVisible(boolean isResultsOverlayVisible)
        Set the visibility of an overlay that shows reading results. When the results overlay is shown it draws rectangular frames around detected counters, giving the user instant feedback that something is being read.

        You should not generally switch off the results overlay unless you provide your own visualization of detected counters.

        Parameters:
        isResultsOverlayVisible - A boolean value indicating whether to display a results overlay or not.

      • isDebugOverlayVisible

        public boolean isDebugOverlayVisible()
        Return the visibility of an overlay that shows debug information.

        The debug overlay is only drawn if the results overlay is also enabled (i.e. isResultsOverlayVisible() returns true).

        Returns:
        true if MeterReadingFragment displays an overlay with debug info. Defaults to false.

      • setDebugOverlayVisible

        public void setDebugOverlayVisible(boolean isDebugOverlayVisible)
        Set the visibility of an overlay that shows debug information.

        The debug overlay is only drawn if the results overlay is also enabled (i.e. isResultsOverlayVisible() returns true).

        The debug overlay is intended for debugging purposes in cooperation with pixolus. You should generally avoid enabling the debug overlay in production builds that are meant to be distributed to end users.

        Parameters:
        isDebugOverlayVisible - set to true if MeterReadingFragment should display an overlay with debug info

      • disableAutoFocus

        public boolean disableAutoFocus()
        Use this method to disable the autofocus operation. Disabling the autofocus can be useful for situations, where no meter reading should be performed but the user should be presented a camera preview. Do not forget to re-enable the autofocus afterwards using enableAutoFocus().
        Returns:
        True, when autofocus was disabled.

      • enableAutoFocus

        public boolean enableAutoFocus()
        Use this method to re-enable the autofocus. After you have disabled the autofocus operation using disableAutoFocus() this method should be used to re-enable the autofocus.
        Returns:
        True, when autofocus was enabled.

        Overrides:
        onSizeChanged in class View

      • setZoom

        public void setZoom(double zoom)
        Set the magnification factor used for camera preview. Default value is 1.

        A magnification factor of 1 means that the visible portion of the preview is maximized under the condition that the whole area of the fragment is covered by the preview. This means that if the preview video has a different aspect ratio than the fragment, the preview is scaled proportionally such that either the width of the preview matches the width of the fragment (cropping top and bottom parts of the preview) or the height of the preview matches the height of the fragment (cropping left and right parts of the preview) but never both. The preview is always centered within the fragment.

        When the magnification factor is larger than 1, the preview is scaled proportionally from the center of the fragment/preview. As a consequence all four edges of the preview will be cropped.

        Note that while this setting affects the scaling of the camera preview, it has no effect on the image supplied via the MeterReadingViewListener.onScanReadings(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView, java.util.List<com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingResult>, android.graphics.Bitmap, com.pixolus.meterreading.Metadata) callback.

        Also note that the fragment only reads meters/counters which are within the visible area of the preview.

        Parameters:
        zoom - The magnification factor.

      • getZoom

        public double getZoom()
        Return the magnification factor used for camera preview.
        Returns:
        The magnification factor.
        See Also:
        setZoom(double)

      • hasTorch

        public boolean hasTorch()
        Return the presence of a torch/flashlight on the device.

        This method shall not be called before CameraViewListener.onCameraViewCameraReady(com.pixolus.meterreading.MeterReadingView) was called. (You may safely call it from your implementation of the onCameraViewCameraReady() callback.)

        Returns:
        true if the device has a torch; false otherwise.
